you're hearing or this week you're hearing a lot about GPUs of course today about FPGAs and the the real concept
behind acceleration of compute a good metaphor for this would be the the
business jet versus the the Shinkansen right the idea behind acceleration is to
take advantage of massive levels of parallelism to increase throughput it's all about throughput right the business
jets a great metaphor for a high end CPU right it goes fast right it carries a
limited number of passengers is very flexible you can turn it go anywhere unlike the Shinkansen and the Shinkansen
is all about throughput it's all about running as many passengers down the line as you can in the given amount of time
it goes relatively fast but not as fast as that is that business jet more
efficient terms of fuel economy right a lot of good metaphors there for accelerated computing so on AWS there's
really two types of accelerators today GPUs and FPGAs the p3 instances that we
announced and launched recently based on Nvidia Volta v100 are outstanding for
doing many types of high performance computing problems accelerating for example double precision
and floating-point computations in finance and engineering and deep learning training on the FPGA side the
f1 based on the Xilinx ultra scale plus devices that's what we'll be talking about at length today but I really want
to characterize how these are different how they sort really serve different needs different applications think about
a GPU a GPU is is really a massively parallel set of compute cores write CUDA
cores as Nvidia refers to them as and these CUDA cores are really optimized
around parallelizing operations for example originally shaders used in
graphics and then later things like financial calculations or engineering calculations double-precision
floating-point calculations that you can parallel eyes in an extreme way using the GPU most recently deep learning
training is an outstanding example of using GPUs to paralyze the problem a GPU
is really a massively many-core architecture right that has at
its heart an instruction set it has data paths that are fixed it has an
architecture that's that's fixed right but it's highly parallel an FPGA on the
other hand this allows you to craft whatever instructions you need with whatever data paths you need whatever
control functions you need it's very flexible from an architecture perspective it does not have an
instruction set unless you create one for it it doesn't have fixed data paths unless you create those yourself so it's
very flexible but it does require more work to develop the applications another
way to view this perhaps schematically right think of the CPU core a modern processor core is going to have multiple
CPU cores each of those CPU cores has multiple al use right arithmetic logic
units it's going to have cache architecture it's going to have you know various control functions in there it's
going to have various layers of memory controllers but it's built to be general-purpose it's built to support
operating systems general purpose applications GPU next step over also has
compute cores that have instruction sets that have a fixed architecture there's just a lot more of them and so the amount of let's
say compute that's being performed for the number of transistors on the chip is
much higher in the GPU than the CPU but it's less general-purpose and then the FPGA as I said there's no instruction
set it's massively parallel there's literally millions of programmable cells in there they're connected by
programmable interconnects and you use different programming methods to program the FPGA because you have to place and
route those those logic cells so very different in different applications that
we can think about for them so our goal with with f1 with the f1 FPGA instances
is to make FPGA is dramatically easier to deploy easier to develop for really
easier to use make FPGA is if you will a first-class citizen in the in the array

attached to your ec2 instance the f1 instance using a PCI Express interface very similar to the p3 instance with the

accelerator card so this allows you to do all kinds of applications in the FPGA

is very important for the types of applications that are deployed on FPGAs
the f1 FPGA instance is available in in two sizes the 2x large and the 16x large
the 2x large has a single FPGA available to you and you can see of course 8 8 B
CPUs and a quite healthy amount of memory some local nvm a storage on the

the FPGA generate the design checkpoint as we call it that gets ingested to
create that AFI all of that can be done on a standard ec2 instance and as I said
you can choose an ec2 instance of the size that's appropriate for the for the

intensive parts of that flow you could choose a larger ec2 instance and importantly as well if you want to

with different parameters to get the best possible performance you can parallelize that as well using standard

your host on the CPU and hdk a hardware development kit that's used for the
development of the logic in the FPGA it's important distinction here
if you're using hardware level design tools the hdk provides all of the
libraries you need to integrate with the Xilinx a development tool flow if you're

provides you those higher-level OpenCL api's from the software side and from
the hardware side when you're developing your fpga logic you're developing what

example that application that you develop will be connected to the
software side via the hdk and what we call the FPGA shell that abstract the
i/o to connect to the software side and we provide you with the necessary
api's necessary hardware interfaces so that you can easily connect those things
together and that's important because if you've done any hardware design in the past any FPGA design you'll know that
designing the i/o can be just as difficult as designing the logic itself
in the application so we help you abstract take care of that i/o and just make it much much easier
